The '''European white egg''' ('''''Amanita ovoidea'''''), '''Bearded Amanita''' or '''European Egg Amidella''', is a species of [[fungus]] of the genus ''[[Amanita]]'' in the family ''[[Amanitaceae]]''. It is a large, white-colored fungus, often  tinged with cream. Native to [[Europe]], it is found on plains as well as mountains in the [[Mediterranean]] region. The species was first described in 1833 by [[Pierre Bulliard]], a French physician and botanist, and [[Lucien Quélet]], a French mycologist and naturalist.

==Description==
[[File:Amanita ovoidea 1.JPG|thumb|left|150px|''A. ovoidea'' mushroom in a forest.]]
The mushroom is white to cream-coloured and can reach very large sizes, over 15 cm, or in exceptional cases over 30 cm. The [[cap (mycology)|cap]] is smooth, fleshy, silky, hemispherical when young, but soon becoming convex to shield shaped. The cap margin is usually covered with hanging, cottony remains of the [[partial veil]]. The [[lamella (mycology)|lamella]]e are thick, rounded, broad and are free from the stipe. The [[stipe (mycology)|stipe]] is thick, cylindrical, powdery, has a fragile, cottony ring, and a large, white to ochraceous-cream [[volva (mycology)|volva]] at the base. The flesh is thick, white and has a strong, unpleasant smell. The [[spore print]] is white, and the elliptical [[basidiospore|spores]] measure 10–12 × 6.5–8 [[μm]].<ref>Galli R. 2007. Le Amanite 2nd Edition. Edinatura.</ref><ref>Neville P, Poumarat S. 2004. Fungi Europaei 9: Amanitae. Edizioni Candusso, Italia.</ref>

''[[Amanita proxima]]'', a poisonous species containing [[allenic norleucine]], is very similar to ''A. ovoidea''. It is separated by the deep ochraceous to russet-orange colour of its volva, the persistent pendulous ring on the stipe, and the smooth cap margin, without vellar remains. ''A. proxima'' is found in the same habitats as ''A. ovoidea'', and can cause cytolytic [[hepatitis]] and [[acute renal failure]].<ref>Ducros J, Labastie J and Saingra S. (1995). Una observation supplementaire d’intoxication par Amanita proxima a  l’origine d’insuffisance renale aigue. Nephrologie, 16: 341.</ref>

==Habitat and ecology==

''Amanita ovoidea'' is a [[symbiotic]] fungus, forming [[mycorrhiza]]l associations with [[pine]] trees, as well as evergreen and deciduous [[oak]]s.<ref name="Roger">{{cite web | url = http://www.rogersmushrooms.com/gallery/DisplayBlock~bid~6951~gid~~source~gallerydefault.asp | title = Amanita ovoidea | accessdate = 2010-05-24 | work = Roger's Mushrooms | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20101231093609/http://www.rogersmushrooms.com/gallery/DisplayBlock~bid~6951~gid~~source~gallerydefault.asp | archive-date = 2010-12-31 | url-status = dead }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=it&u=http://www.agraria.org/funghi/amanitaovoidea.htm&ei=d-n5S9yEOozaNueEmYQI&sa=X&oi=translate&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CD8Q7gEwCDgU&prev=/search%3Fq%3DAmanita%2Bovoidea%26start%3D20%26hl%3Den%26lr%3D%26sa%3DN%26prmd%3Di | title = Amanita ovoidea (Bull.: Fr) | accessdate = 2010-05-24 | work = Agraria}}</ref> It is found in [[coniferous forests]], [[deciduous forests]], coastal regions, mountains, roadsides and grassy areas,<ref name="Roger"/><ref name=tulloss>{{cite web|last=R E|first=Tulloss|title=Amanita ovoidea|url=http://pluto.njcc.com/~ret/amanita/species/ovoideas.html}}</ref> growing on limy, sandy and alkaline soils.<ref name=rdb>{{cite web|title=Amanita ovoidea|url=http://e-ecodb.bas.bg/rdb/en/vol1/Amaovoid.html|publisher=Red Data Book of Bulgaria}}</ref>

In Bulgaria, the species is in danger due to [[habitat loss]] caused by selective logging, human settlements and natural causes like acid rain and soil pollution.<ref name="rdb"/>

==Edibility/Toxicity==
The edibility of ''Amanita ovoidea'' is dubious. In the past, the fungus has been reported as "edible" in some books and "poisonous" in others. Moreover, it can easily be confused with other all-white, deadly poisonous ''Amanita'' species, such as ''[[Amanita virosa]]'', ''[[Amanita verna]]'' and, in particular, ''[[Amanita proxima]]''.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://translate.googleusercontent.com/translate_c?hl=en&sl=es&u=http://www.fungipedia.es/clasificacion-orden/basidiomycetes/65-agaricales/162-amanita-ovoidea.html&prev=/search%3Fq%3DAmanita%2Bovoidea%26hl%3Den%26lr%3D%26sa%3DN%26prmd%3Di&rurl=translate.google.com&twu=1&usg=ALkJrhgdO_UQP2djVC8YYii8dM_5mn-3OQ | title = Amanita ovoid | accessdate = 2010-05-24 | last = Pérez Calvo200 | first = Javi | date = 2009-01-23 | work = Fungipedia}}</ref> In southern [[France]], some people were inflicted with [[acute kidney injury]] because they accidentally consumed ''A. proxima'', mistaking it for ''A. ovoidea''.<ref>de Haro L, Jouglard J, Arditti J, David JM. (1998). Acute renal insufficiency caused by Amanita proxima poisoning: experience of the Poison Center of Marseille. Nephrologie (19): 21–4.</ref><ref>Leray H, Canaud B, Andary C, Klouche K, Béraud JJ and Mion C. (1994). Intoxication par Amanita proxima.  Néphrologie 15: 197-199.</ref> Similar cases of poisoning have also been reported from [[Cyprus]].<ref>Loizides M., Kyriakou T., Tziakouris A. (2011). Edible & Toxic Fungi of Cyprus. 1st Edition, 304 p. {{ISBN|978-9963-7380-0-7}}</ref><ref>Loizides M, Bellanger JM, Yiangou Y, Moreau PA. (2018). Preliminary phylogenetic investigations into the genus ''Amanita'' (Agaricales) in Cyprus, with a review of previous records and poisoning incidents. Documents Mycologiques 37, 201–218.</ref>

A study on the [[minerals]] in [[fungi]] from northwest [[Turkey]], including this species, concluded ''A. ovoidea'' was safe to eat and could fulfill nutritional needs.<ref>{{cite journal | title = Minor element and heavy metal content of edible wild mushrooms native to Bolu, North-West Turkey | journal = Fresenius Environmental Bulletin | date = 2008 | volume = 17 | issue = 2 | pages = 249–252 | url = http://md1.csa.com/partners/viewrecord.php?requester=gs&collection=ENV&recid=8113166&q=amanita+ovoidea&uid=789486094&setcookie=yes | accessdate = 2010-05-24 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120322062814/http://md1.csa.com/partners/viewrecord.php?requester=gs&collection=ENV&recid=8113166&q=amanita+ovoidea&uid=789486094&setcookie=yes | archive-date = 2012-03-22 | url-status = dead }}</ref>
